title: Ticket #2919: Parallelize classad matchmaking
description:
As part of my ME964 project, I am working to find points where ClassAd work can be done in a parallel fashion. The first step is seeing if matching of classads can be parallelized.

Currently matching is done using the IsAMatch function inside compat_classad_util. This operation can be parallelized by passing in the classad we want a match for and a list of candidates and, perhaps using openmp, by using a parallel for loop to create MatchClassAd instances for each potential pair. Because the original classads are modified during the matching operation, we would need to make copies of the target classad, as depending on the classad we are matching against, the change is different. The original candidate classads can be modified themselves.

One possible performance enhancement is to create a pool of MatchClassAd instances that the parallel matching algorithm can use instead of constantly creating and destroying MatchClassAd instances, assuming this is ever a problem.
remarks:
2012-Apr-06 20:58:10 by ziliang:
Some preliminary numbers where I am trying to find a match for a job from amongst 1136 machines. Note that each pair of numbers is using a different job ad but the same set of machines. Also note that I am not stopping the search the moment I find a match, this is a straight up comparison to see how much time it would take to run a comparison against all the machines.

Job 1:

  • OpenMP: 1404
  • Sequential: 1435

Job 2:

  • OpenMP: 1404
  • Sequential: 2636

Job 3:

  • OpenMP: 2418
  • Sequential: 4399

Job 4:

  • OpenMP: 1653
  • Sequential: 5226

Comments: This is running with 4 threads for each comparison, since that's how many cores I have on my workstation. My implementation sets that the amount of threads equal to the number of cores. The first job also had to initialize the memory pool used to hold the MatchAd classes and the copies of the target ad. We need a better way to clean those up. This speedup for the others is also, unfortunately, not linear. That may have something to do with the synchronization that happens to add matching ads to the shared vector. Am open to suggestions of how to make that more efficient. Another possibility is the cost of the copying operation I have to do for the target ad, which is not done in the sequential matching.

2012-May-15 15:38:16 by ziliang:
We'll need to declare openmp as a dependency in the packaging glue if we roll this out.

2016-Sep-27 10:40:06 by gthain:
Let's leave this one undocumented until it has some more mileage under its belt.
